title: World's first 9-ton railgun fires 20-megajoule blast at Mach 7 to smash missiles
text:
World’s first 9-ton railgun fires 20-megajoule blast at Mach 7 to smash missiles
In earlier tests, the weapon reached a muzzle velocity of about 2,230 meters per second, or Mach 6.5.
World’s first 9-ton hypersonic railgun fires 20-megajoule blast to smash missiles.
Japan has released new images of its ship-mounted railgun firing from the test ship JS Asuka on September 10, marking a milestone in the country’s push to develop directed-energy weapons for the Japan Self-Defense Forces.
The Acquisition, Technology and Logistics Agency (ATLA), an arm of the Defense Ministry that manages research, procurement, and technology support, said it conducted the shipboard railgun test from June to early July with support from the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force.
It was the first time Japan had shown images of the railgun in action while mounted on a real vessel.
World’s first 20-megajoule giant railgun
The Fleet Research and Development Command operates the ship as a technology demonstrator.
ATLA has overseen the program with industrial support from Japan Steel Works, one of the nation’s premier naval gun manufacturers.
Japan formally launched its electromagnetic railgun effort in 2016 and began live-fire testing in 2022.
Early research focused on two technical hurdles that have stymied similar programs abroad: keeping projectiles stable at hypersonic speeds and reducing barrel wear caused by extreme stresses.
September 10, 2025
Railguns accelerate projectiles with electric and magnetic fields, producing immense forces that can rapidly degrade internal components.
The US Navy canceled its publicly acknowledged railgun project in 2021 after spending more than $500 million.
According to Defense News, the American prototype suffered severe barrel degradation after fewer than 30 firings, prompting Washington to shift its public emphasis toward solid-state laser systems.
Those weapons have faced inconsistent field performance and limited operational readiness.
7x speed of sound
Japan’s current railgun prototype, mounted on Asuka, reportedly weighs about eight metric tons (nine US tons) and has a six-meter barrel.
Open-source analysis cited by Shephard Media indicates the system launches 40-millimeter steel projectiles weighing roughly 320 grams (0.7 pounds).
In earlier tests, the weapon reached a muzzle velocity of about 2,230 meters per second, or Mach 6.5, and planners aim to boost its charge energy from 5 megajoules to a projected 20 megajoules.
Unlike traditional explosive ordnance, the railgun relies on pure kinetic energy for destructive effect, firing inert projectiles at hypersonic speed.
This makes it a cost-effective alternative to guided missiles in certain roles. Concept diagrams suggest projectiles could be configured for multiple missions, including anti-air fragmentation.
Railguns also avoid the line-of-sight limits and atmospheric attenuation that hinder laser weapons, offering all-weather capability and potential over-the-horizon engagements, a significant advantage at sea.
Japanese defense planners have studied pairing railguns with long-range intercept systems to strengthen layered air defense against threats such as hypersonic glide vehicles and massed drone swarms.
The Red Sea confrontations, where expensive interceptors have been used against low-cost drones, have underscored the economic challenges of missile-centric defenses.
RECOMMENDED ARTICLES
Railguns have the potential to hold more ammunition and cost less per shot. These factors could change how we approach warfare that relies on a steady supply and attrition.
Japan is making important strides in energy-based weaponry, an area that has long promised much but has not delivered. However, it is now getting closer to being ready for actual use.
